column1: These may include: - Physical exam - Mammogram - Breast MRI - Breast Ultrasound - Breast Biopsy, either ultrasound or stereotactic - Chest x-ray - CT scan - Bone scan - PET Scan Pathological staging uses the results from lab tests done on breast tissue and lymph nodes removed during surgery.
It tells whether the cancer has spread to parts of the body away from the breast.
This is cancer that is confined to the lobules or ducts in the breast.
Lobules are parts of the breast that produce milk.
Ducts carry the milk to the nipple.
There may be no tumor found in the breast, but cancer can be found that has spread to axillary lymph nodes or nodes close to the breastbone.
There might also be a tumor between 2 and 5 centimeters in the breast with small cancers in some of the lymph nodes.
Or the tumor could be larger than 5 centimeters with no cancer in the nodes.
Cancer of any size has spread to at least 10 axillary nodes.
With stage I, II, or III breast cancer, the main goal is to cure the cancer by treating it and keeping it from coming back.
